title: If ADCs are so shit, why do people continue to play them????

replies.body:
Because they aren't shit.

ADC players are used to the absurd amount of early power they were able to abuse after the Marksman and mage updates by abusing assassin items and such.

This is imo more in line with how Adc's should be in terms of balance, tho i feel that ADC's are too strong late and could use a bit more power midgame.

Right now, Early game bullies can bully early game but still become absurd late.
Champs like Ashe, Varus and Jhin that trade lategame power for Utility are more balanced imo.
Champs like Vayne and Twitch Take a bit to long to get rolling but become utterly broken when they reach a certain point in the game.

Marksman need to stop having this stigma where they have to be busted late game and each have power curves more in line with every other champion class.

Lane bullies like Draven are too strong late, while utility marksman are more consistent if a bit too strong late, while Lategame carries like vayne and Twitch are absurd to justify them over the lane bullies that are strong late.

The short version is that people play them because they provide a service no other class of champion does (there may be individual exceptions within classes, but no other class _as a whole_ does this).

Specifically they bring down objectives, particularly towers and inhibitors, relatively quickly with ranged autos.
The **ranged **autos bit is important because it means that, typically, if the siege goes pearshaped and the opposing team attempts to jump the sieging team, the siegers are likely to be able to get out from under tower range. If they don't get locked down entirely, they are very likely a mere 1 movement skill/other positioning tool away from not having to fight under the enemy tower.

The ranged **autos** means the damage to the objective is largely smoothly and consistently delivered. It's predictable, doesn't consume resources, doesn't come with opportunity costs (e.g.: Ziggs has a turret execute on his Satchel Charge, but has to consider whether he should use it because if he does, he has approximately jack and shit for mobility or escapes if there's a gank incoming. Using the skill creates a window of weakness for him, which AAing does not for an ADC). 

Compare and contrast, for example attempting to bring down a tower with a team that is 100% melee. If you get caught, at best you give the opposing team several more seconds to land stuns etc. etc. under tower, at worst are forced to stand and fight  while taking 4-5 tower shots. Your tank might not care but your carries sure will.

So short version: People play ADCs because the game is won by taking objectives. It doesn't matter how many kills your team has, if the other team takes your Nexus. And while there are plenty of other champions better at securing control over an objective, or the area around it, there are comparitively few non-ADCs who are as good at doing the high amounts of consistent, low-risk DPS needed to safely/efficiently take objectives.
